schema.description: TODO: Just like parameters, this should be linted for. If you define an interface that's not declared here, that should ring a bell.

relative file path from the project-root to the operation (DOES include operation folder)

e.g. /tools/cognition/typescript/index-typescript

relative file path from the operation src

e.g. general.ts

file id (same as relativeFilePathFromSrc but without extension)

e.g. "general"
operation package.json name
operation folder name (by convention, must be identical to operationName, but it could have some mistakes)
relative file or folder path from the project root
unique id of the model
name (identifier) of the model
kebab-case variant of the name
all info that should always be collected when indexing any type interface

Meta schema

Recommended values:
- 'http://json-schema.org/schema#'
- 'http://json-schema.org/hyper-schema#'
- 'http://json-schema.org/draft-07/schema#'
- 'http://json-schema.org/draft-07/hyper-schema#'
Primitive type
Primitive type
JSON Schema v7
JSON Schema v7
JSON Schema v7
JSON Schema v7
JSON Schema v7
JSON Schema v7
JSON Schema v7
JSON Schema v7
JSON Schema v7
JSON Schema v7
Primitive type
Primitive type

JSONSchema7 derivative that has the following capabilities and and characteristics...

- does not include objects in objects that are also referenced to using xxxSlug or xxxId
- recursively finds the references and expands them, unless the references are circular
- easier to read
- has all the information we need
- is able to generate an object with values in the exact format the function needs it
- is able to easily generate a form
sometimes we still need to reference to another schema because this thing is recursive. In that case the ref name will be here
in case of enums this could appear... mostly strings, but e.g. numbers can also be an enum I think
Primitive type
in case of object, this will always appear
NB: can't we put this in the SimplifiedSchema itself?
in case of arrays, this will always appear
name in case of it being a reference, otherwise null
if the type is an object, this is true. false if it's an array
if the type is an array, this is true
if it's a primitive type like "string", "number", "boolean", "null" | "undefined"
will be true for any primitive conjunction types
will be true for string conjunction types
quantification of coverage of the specified type or subtypes in our database.
raw type string
a string that is known to contain markdown.

comments are basically one-or-multi-line human content inside of typescript files, so it's a very important to do something useful with them.

special line prefixes:
- TODO:
- DISCUSSION:
- IDEA:
- LATER:
- NB:

The convention should be that single-line comments should start with that. This then becomes the type of the comment. You can also put multiple prefixes at the start.

Example:

`// TODO: NB: this is a todo but its also important`

Multiline comments can also have one or multiple types in their text, but they should not be split into multiple comments as the context could be needed some times.



There are also some other things comments can say about statements, but these should be inside the frontmatter, and are much more flexible.
- classified[0-10] indicating level of classification. This way I can share subsets of the codebase, maybe...
- privacy
- ...?

NB: with the current setup we can also parse `.md` files as being a TsComment, keep it that way!

NB: comments are part of the code, so they should always be in English!

relative file path from the project-root to the operation (DOES include operation folder)

e.g. /tools/cognition/typescript/index-typescript

relative file path from the operation src

e.g. general.ts

file id (same as relativeFilePathFromSrc but without extension)

e.g. "general"
operation package.json name
operation folder name (by convention, must be identical to operationName, but it could have some mistakes)
relative file or folder path from the project root
unique id of the model
name (identifier) of the model
kebab-case variant of the name
a string that is known to contain markdown.
These are the type indicators that were found in this single or multiline comment. Can be multiple.
first line of the comment
last line of the comment
statement name the comment belongs to
raw statement text the comment belongs to
raw interface text, coming from ts-morph
if the interface extends anything, names will be specified here

if true, this interface is marked as a db model, which means it will be included in the db function autocompletion so it's easy to store and fetch data in this format.

is automatically set to true when indexing and when one of the following statements holds true
- if the doc-comment contains frontmatter with `isDbModel` or `defaultDbStorageMethod` specified
- if the interface last word is "db" or "model" and if there are minimum 2 words
- if the interface extends some other special interface

name: TsInterface
description: TODO: Just like parameters, this should be linted for. If you define an interface that's not declared here, that should ring a bell.

relativeOperationBasePathFromProjectRoot.description:
relative file path from the project-root to the operation (DOES include operation folder)

e.g. /tools/cognition/typescript/index-typescript

relativeFilePathFromSrc.description:
relative file path from the operation src

e.g. general.ts

srcFileId.description:
file id (same as relativeFilePathFromSrc but without extension)

e.g. "general"

operationFolderName.description: operation folder name (by convention, must be identical to operationName, but it could have some mistakes)

relativePathFromProjectRoot.description: relative file or folder path from the project root

description.description: jsdoc comment above the interface, if any

rawText.description: raw interface text, coming from ts-morph

extensions.description: if the interface extends anything, names will be specified here

isDbModel.description:
if true, this interface is marked as a db model, which means it will be included in the db function autocompletion so it's easy to store and fetch data in this format.

is automatically set to true when indexing and when one of the following statements holds true
- if the doc-comment contains frontmatter with `isDbModel` or `defaultDbStorageMethod` specified
- if the interface last word is "db" or "model" and if there are minimum 2 words
- if the interface extends some other special interface

defaultDbStorageMethod.description:
if this interface is a db model, you can also specify the default db storage method for it. You can do this by specifying it in the frontmatter of the doccomment of the interface.

When storing something into the database, this value can be overwritten in your query configuration. When fetching something from the database, it will always try all methods (unless specified otherwise). The following strategies are available to store the data.

jsonMultiple (default): stores the data in a json file which is an array of this data structure

TODO: jsonSingle: stores the data in a json file which is of this data structure (single object)

TODO: markdown: stores the data in a markdown file. Takes "markdown" or "description" parameter as the main markdown. The other parameters are stored as front-matter

TODO: keyValueMarkdown: stores the data in key value markdown format. Still need to determine how and if this is possible. Probably only for very simple datamodels

TODO: csv: stores the data in a csv file (only possible for flat object datastructures)

name: PathParse
description:
object to represent a folder or file path in different ways

NB: doesn't include the absolute path so the indexes can be exported easily witout creating incorrect paths

relativePathFromProjectRoot.description: relative file or folder path from the project root

object to represent a folder or file path in different ways

name: TypeInfo
description: all info that should always be collected when indexing any type interface

typeDefinition.description:
JSON schema definition of a type interface


Some info about the Schema:

- if the type is an object, there should be properties
- if the type is an array, there should be items

isObject.description: if the type is an object, this is true. false if it's an array

isArray.description: if the type is an array, this is true

isPrimitive.description: if it's a primitive type like "string", "number", "boolean", "null" | "undefined"

isEnum.description: will be true for any primitive conjunction types

isEnumLiteral.description: will be true for string conjunction types

typeDefinition.description: all info that should always be collected when indexing any type interface

simplifiedSchema.description: all info that should always be collected when indexing any type interface

name: SimplifiedSchema
description:
JSONSchema7 derivative that has the following capabilities and and characteristics...

- does not include objects in objects that are also referenced to using xxxSlug or xxxId
- recursively finds the references and expands them, unless the references are circular
- easier to read
- has all the information we need
- is able to generate an object with values in the exact format the function needs it
- is able to easily generate a form

type.description:
- string
- number
- boolean
- object
- array
- null

NB: Omit doesn't work for the indexer! This would be the type: Omit<JSONSchema7TypeName, "integer">;

circularRefName.description: sometimes we still need to reference to another schema because this thing is recursive. In that case the ref name will be here

enum.description: in case of enums this could appear... mostly strings, but e.g. numbers can also be an enum I think

properties.description: in case of object, this will always appear

items.description: in case of arrays, this will always appear

name: TsComment
description:
comments are basically one-or-multi-line human content inside of typescript files, so it's a very important to do something useful with them.

special line prefixes:
- TODO:
- DISCUSSION:
- IDEA:
- LATER:
- NB:

The convention should be that single-line comments should start with that. This then becomes the type of the comment. You can also put multiple prefixes at the start.

Example:

`// TODO: NB: this is a todo but its also important`

Multiline comments can also have one or multiple types in their text, but they should not be split into multiple comments as the context could be needed some times.



There are also some other things comments can say about statements, but these should be inside the frontmatter, and are much more flexible.
- classified[0-10] indicating level of classification. This way I can share subsets of the codebase, maybe...
- privacy
- ...?

NB: with the current setup we can also parse `.md` files as being a TsComment, keep it that way!

NB: comments are part of the code, so they should always be in English!

relativeOperationBasePathFromProjectRoot.description:
relative file path from the project-root to the operation (DOES include operation folder)

e.g. /tools/cognition/typescript/index-typescript

relativeFilePathFromSrc.description:
relative file path from the operation src

e.g. general.ts

srcFileId.description:
file id (same as relativeFilePathFromSrc but without extension)

e.g. "general"

operationFolderName.description: operation folder name (by convention, must be identical to operationName, but it could have some mistakes)

relativePathFromProjectRoot.description: relative file or folder path from the project root

comment.description: the content of the comment in markdown, without frontmatter

parameters.description: parameters destructured from the frontmatter of the parsed markdown (if comment is not a oneliner, otherwise it'll be empty)

types.description: These are the type indicators that were found in this single or multiline comment. Can be multiple.

statementName.description: statement name the comment belongs to

rawStatement.description: raw statement text the comment belongs to
